*Today’s Verses:*

*Jesus asked, **“How can I describe the Kingdom of *

*Heaven? **What story should I use to illustrate it? *

*It is like a tiny Must**ard seed. Though it is one of *

*t**he smallest of seeds, yet it grows** to become one *

*of the largest plants, with long branches** where *

*birds can come and find shelter .*(Mk. 4:30-32)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus used this parable to explain that although

Christianity had very small beginnings, it would

grow into a world-wide community of believers.

When you feel alone in your stand for Christ, real-

ize that God is building a worldwide Kingdom.

He has faithful followers in every part of the

world, *and your faith no matter how small, *

*can **join with that **of others to accomplish *

*great things.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text: Jesus used this parable to explain that although Christianity had very small beginnings, it would grow into a worldwide community of believers. When you feel alone in your stand for Christ, real ize that God is building a worldwide Kingdom. He has faithful followers in every part of the world, and your faith no matter how small, can join with that of others to accomplish great things.
original_verse_text: Jesus asked, “How can I describe the Kingdom of  Heaven? What story should I use to illustrate it?  It is like a tiny Mustard seed. Though it is one of  the smallest of seeds, yet it grows to become one  of the largest plants, with long branches where  birds can come and find shelter .
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts of gratitude for the promise of Your kingdom. Though our faith may feel small, we trust in Your power to grow it and use it for Your glory. Help us to remember that we are not alone, but part of a worldwide community of believers united in Your love. May our lives bear witness to the transformative work of Your Spirit, that others may be drawn to the hope found in Your Son, Jesus Christ. Amen.
reflection: Jesus used this parable to explain that although Christianity had very small beginnings, it would grow into a worldwide community of believers. When you feel alone in your stand for Christ, realize that God is building a worldwide Kingdom. He has faithful followers in every part of the world, and your faith, no matter how small, can join with that of others to accomplish great things.

message_id: 176256eace980338
subject   : Subject: WHY SOME MAY RESIST IT (12-3-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Wed, 2 Dec 2020 15:49:39 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):
===================================================================
*Today’s Verses:*

*Their judgment is based on this fact: The light from *

*heaven came into the world, but they loved the dark-*

*ness more then the light, for their actions were evil. *

*They hate the light because they want to sin in the *

*darkness. They stay away from the light for their sins *

*will be exposed and they will be punished. *

(Jn. 3:19-20)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Many people don’t want their lives exposed to God’s

light because they are afraid of what will be revealed.

They don’t want to be changed. Don’t be surprised

when these same people are threatened by your desire

to obey God and do what is right, because they are

afraid that the light in you may expose some of the

darkness in their lives. *Rather* *then giving into dis-*

*courage**ment, keep praying that* *they will come to *

*see how much better it is to live in* *Light **rather *

*than darkness.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text: Many people don’t want their lives exposed to God’s light because they are afraid of what will be revealed. They don’t want to be changed. Don’t be surprised when these same people are threatened by your desire to obey God and do what is right, because they are afraid that the light in you may expose some of the darkness in their lives. Rather then giving into dis couragement, keep praying that they will come to see how much better it is to live in Light rather than darkness.
original_verse_text: Their judgment is based on this fact: The light from  heaven came into the world, but they loved the dark- ness more then the light, for their actions were evil.  They hate the light because they want to sin in the  darkness. They stay away from the light for their sins  will be exposed and they will be punished.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, acknowledging that the light of Your truth can be uncomfortable for those who love darkness. Help us to walk boldly in the light of Your Son, Jesus, the Light of the World. May our lives be a beacon, drawing others to the freedom and transformation that comes from living in Your presence. Give us the courage to stand firm in our faith, even when it challenges the darkness around us. We pray that those who are afraid of Your light would see the beauty and life that it brings. In Your name, we pray. Amen.
reflection: Many people don't want their lives exposed to God's light because they are afraid of what will be revealed. They don't want to be changed. Don't be surprised when these same people are threatened by your desire to obey God and do what is right, because they are afraid that the light in you may expose some of the darkness in their lives. Rather than giving into discouragement, keep praying that they will come to see how much better it is to live in light rather than darkness.

message_id: 1762aca42a51d43d
subject   : Subject: JESUS' RESURRECTION IS THE KEY (12-4-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Thu, 3 Dec 2020 16:47:47 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):
===================================================================
*Today’s Verses:*

*He isn’t here! He has risen from the dead! Don’t you *

*remember** what He told you back in Galilee, that the *

*Son of Man must be** betrayed into the hands of sinful *

*men and be crucified, and that **He would rise again *

*on the third day?” *(Lk. 24:6-7)


*Today’s Reflection:*

*Why is the Resurrection important?*

(1) Because Christ was raised from the dead we know

that our world is now headed for redemption not disaster.

(2) Because of the Resurrection, we know that death

has been conquered and we, too, will be raised from the

dead to live forever with Christ.

(3) Because the Resurrection gives authority to the

church’s witness in the world.

(4) Because the Resurrection gives meaning to the

church’s sacrament of the Lord’s Supper.

(5) Because the Resurrection gives meaning even

in great tragedy

(6) Because the Resurrection assures us that Christ

is alive and ruling His kingdom, He is alive and well.

*(7) **God’s power that brought Jesus back from *

*the dead **is available to us so that we can live for *

*Him in the evil world.*

*Pastor Sather*

(5) Because the Resurrection gives meaning even in great tragedy (6) Because the Resurrection assures us that Christ is alive and ruling His kingdom, He is alive and well. (7) God’s power that brought Jesus back from the dead is available to us so that we can live for Him in the evil world.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we give thanks for the glorious Resurrection of our Lord Jesus Christ. Through His triumph over the grave, we know that death has been conquered and that we, too, will be raised to eternal life with You. May the power that raised Christ from the dead fill us with hope and empower us to live for Your kingdom in this fallen world. We trust in Your redemptive plan and the promise of new life in Christ. Amen.

original_content:
message_id: 17630048a96ce374
subject   : Subject: GOD'S SPIRIT AT WORK (12-06-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Fri, 4 Dec 2020 17:09:33 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):
===================================================================
*Today’s Verses:*

*Godly Jews from many nations were living in Jerusalem *

*at that time. When they heard this sound they came running *

*to see what it was all about, and they were amazed to here*

*their language being spoken by the believers. They were*

*beside themselves with wonder. “How can this be?” they*

*exclaimed these people are all from Galilee, and yet we*

*hear them speaking in the language of the lands where*

*we were born? *(Acts 2:5-8)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Christianity is not limited to any race or group of people.

Christ offers salvation to all people without regard to

nationality. Visitors in Jerusalem were surprised to hear

the apostles and other believers speaking in languages

other than their own, the languages of other nationalities,

but they didn’t need to be, because God works all kinds

of miracles to spread the Good News, using many lang-

uages as He calls all kinds of people to become His

followers. *No matter what your race, color or nation-*

*ality or language, God speaks to you. Are you listen-*

*ing **to Him?*

* Pastor Sather*

They were beside themselves with wonder. “How can this be?” they exclaimed these people are all from Galilee, and yet we hear them speaking in the language of the lands where we were born?

We thank You for the miraculous work of Your Spirit, using diverse languages to spread the Good News of salvation through Jesus Christ. Open our hearts to hear Your voice, and empower us to be Your witnesses, that all may come to know the riches of Your kingdom. In Your Son's name, we pray. Amen.

original_content:
message_id: 1763510a813fead1
subject   : Subject: EARLY CHRISTIAN RELATIONSHIP WITH JUDAISM (12-6-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Sat, 5 Dec 2020 16:40:53 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):
===================================================================
*Today’s Verse: *

*They worshiped together each day at the temple, met *

*in **homes for the Lord’s Supper., and shared their meals *

*with great joy. *(Acts. 3:46)



*Today’s reflection:*

The common misconception about first Christians

(who were Jews) was that they rejected the Jewish

religion. But these believers saw Jesus message and

resurrection as the fulfilment of everything they

believed from the Old Testament. The Jewish believers

at first did not separate themselves from the rest of the

Jewish community. They still went to the Temple and synagogue for worship
and instruction in the Scriptures.

But their belief in Jesus created great friction with Jews

who did not believe that Jesus *was the messiah.* So believing

Jews were forced to meet in private homes for Communion, prayer. and
teaching about Christ. *By the end of the first century, many* *of these
Jewish believers were excom-*

*municated from the synagogue.*

* Pastor Sather *
original_reflection_text:
The common misconception about first Christians (who were Jews) was that they rejected the Jewish religion. But these believers saw Jesus message and resurrection as the fulfillment of everything they
believed from the Old Testament. The Jewish believers at first did not separate themselves from the rest of the Jewish community. They still went to the Temple and synagogue for worship and instruction in the Scriptures. But their belief in Jesus created great friction with Jews who did not believe that Jesus was the messiah. So believing Jews were forced to meet in private homes for Communion, prayer. and teaching about Christ. By the end of the first century, many of these Jewish believers were excom municated from the synagogue.
original_verse_text: They worshiped together each day at the temple, met  in homes for the Lord’s Supper., and shared their meals  with great joy.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we give thanks for the steadfast faith of the early believers in Jerusalem. Though they faced persecution and division, they remained devoted to Your Word, to fellowship, and to the breaking of bread. Help us, like them, to hold fast to the truth of Your Son, Jesus Christ, and to worship and serve You with unity of heart. May our lives be a testimony to Your saving grace, that others may come to know You. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: The common misconception about first Christians (who were Jews) was that they rejected the Jewish religion. But these believers saw Jesus message and resurrection as the fulfillment of everything they believed from the Old Testament. The Jewish believers at first did not separate themselves from the rest of the Jewish community. They still went to the Temple and synagogue for worship and instruction in the Scriptures. But their belief in Jesus created great friction with Jews who did not believe that Jesus was the messiah. So believing Jews were forced to meet in private homes for Communion, prayer. and teaching about Christ. By the end of the first century, many of these Jewish believers were excom municated from the synagogue.
subject: Early Christian Relationship with Judaism

subject   : Subject: A PAINFUL DEPARTURE (12-7-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

date      : Sun, 6 Dec 2020 16:35:10 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

*Today’s Verse:*

*Now turn from your sins and turn to God, so that *

*you can **be cleansed of your sins. *(Acts. 3:19)



*Today’s Reflection:*

When we turn from sin, God promises not only

to cleanse us of sins but to bring spiritual refresh-

ment. Turning away from sin may at first seem

painful because it is hard to break old habits and

give up certain sins. But God will give you a

better way, as Hosea Promised, “Oh that we

might know the Lord! Let us press on to know

Him! Then He will respond to us as surely as

the rising of the sun or the coming of the rains

in early spring.” (Hosea 6:3). *Do you feel a *

*need to be refreshed?*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
When we turn from sin, God promises not only to cleanse us of sins but to bring spiritual refresh ment. Turning away from sin may at first seem painful because it is hard to break old habits and give up certain sins. But God will give you a better way, as Hosea Promised, “Oh that we
might know the Lord! Let us press on to know Him! Then He will respond to us as surely as the rising of the sun or the coming of the rains in early spring.” (Hosea 6:3). Do you feel a need to be refreshed?
original_verse_text: Now turn from your sins and turn to God, so that  you can be cleansed of your sins.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, acknowledging our need to turn from our sins and press on to know You more deeply. As Hosea promised, we long for the refreshment and restoration that comes from Your presence. Lord, grant us the courage to repent and the grace to receive Your cleansing and reviving Spirit. May we experience the joy of Your salvation and the hope of Your eternal promises. Amen.
reflection: When we turn from sin, God promises not only to cleanse us of sins but to bring spiritual refreshment. Turning away from sin may at first seem painful because it is hard to break old habits and give up certain sins. But God will give you a better way, as Hosea promised, "Oh that we might know the Lord! Let us press on to know Him! Then He will respond to us as surely as the rising of the sun or the coming of the rains in early spring." (Hosea 6:3). Do you feel a need to be refreshed?
subject: A Painful Departure
verse_text: Now turn from your sins and turn to God, so that  you can be cleansed of your sins.

*Today’s Verse:*

*The sacrifice you want is a broken spirit. A broken **and **repentant
heart, O God, You will not despise. *(Ps. 51:17)

*Today’s Reflection:*

God wants a broken spirit *and* a broken and repentant heart. You can never
please God

by outward actions—no matter how good—

if your heart attitude is not right. Are you

sorry for your sins? Do you genuinely

intend to stop? *God is pleased by this *

*kind of repentance!*

* Pastor Sather *
original_reflection_text:
God wants a broken spirit and a broken and repentant heart.
You can never please God by outward actions-no matter how good if your heart attitude is not right. Are you sorry for your sins? Do you genuinely intend to stop? God is pleased by this kind of repentance!
original_verse_text: The sacrifice you want is a broken spirit. A broken and repentant heart, O God, You will not despise.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble and contrite hearts, acknowledging our need for Your grace and forgiveness. We recognize that it is not our outward actions, but the condition of our hearts that matters most to You. Lord, create in us a clean heart and renew a right spirit within us, that we may walk in obedience to Your ways. We pray for the gift of a broken and repentant spirit, that we may find true joy and peace in Your presence. Amen.
reflection: God wants a broken spirit and a broken and repentant heart. You can never please God by outward actions—no matter how good—if your heart attitude is not right. Are you sorry for your sins? Do you genuinely intend to stop? God is pleased by this kind of repentance!

subject   : Subject: LIGHT IN OUR DARKNESS (12-9-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Tue, 8 Dec 2020 17:01:20 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

*Today’s Verse:*

*The Lord is my light and my salvation—so why*

*should I **be afraid? The Lord protects me from *

*danger—so why **should I tremble? *(Ps. 27:1)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Fear is a dark shadow that envelops us and

ultimately imprisons us within ourselves.

Each of us has been a prisoner of fear at

one time or another—fear of rejection,

misunderstanding, uncertainty, sickness,

or even death. But we can conquer fear by

using the bright liberating light of the Lord,

who brings salvation. If we want to dispel

the darkness of fear, let us remember the

psalmist that “*the Lord is my light and *

*my salvation*.”

* Pastor Sather *

Fear is a dark shadow that envelops us and ultimately imprisons us within ourselves. Each of us has been a prisoner of fear at one time or another-fear of rejection,

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts filled with fear and uncertainty. The darkness of this world often threatens to overwhelm us, but we cling to the truth that You are our light and our salvation. Help us to cast aside the shackles of fear and trust in Your perfect peace that surpasses all understanding. May we find refuge in Your presence, resting in the knowledge that You are our strength and our shield. In Your mighty name, we pray. Amen.
reflection: Fear is a dark shadow that envelops us and ultimately imprisons us within ourselves. Each of us has been a prisoner of fear at one time or another—fear of rejection, misunderstanding, uncertainty, sickness, or even death. But we can conquer fear by using the bright, liberating light of the Lord, who brings salvation. If we want to dispel the darkness of fear, let us remember the psalmist that "the Lord is my light and my salvation."

original_content:
message_id: 17649a311948fed8
subject   : Subject: THE CONSEQUENCE OF REJECTING THE HOLY SPIRIT (12-10-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Wed, 9 Dec 2020 16:33:12 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):
===================================================================
*Today’s Verse:*

*Dear friends, if we deliberately continue sinning*

*after we have received the full knowledge of the*

*truth, there is no other sacrifice that will cover*

*these sins*. (Heb. 10:26)



*Today’s Reflection:*

When people deliberately reject Christ’s offer of

salvation, the reject God’s most precious gift

they ignore the leading of the Holy Spirit, the

One who communicates to us God’s saving love.

This warning was given to the Jewish Christians

who were tempted to reject Christ for another

religion or, having understood Christ’s atoning

work. If anyone deliberately rejects the sacrifice

of Christ after clearly understanding the Good

News teaching about it, that there is no way for

that person to be saved, because *God does not*

*provide any other name in all of heaven for*

*people to call on to save them.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
When people deliberately reject Christ’s offer of
salvation, the reject God’s most precious gift
they ignore the leading of the Holy Spirit, the
One who communicates to us God’s saving love.
This warning was given to the Jewish Christians
who were tempted to reject Christ for another
religion or, having understood Christ’s atoning
work. If anyone deliberately rejects the sacrifice
of Christ after clearly understanding the Good
News teaching about it, that there is no way for
that person to be saved, because God does not provide any other name in all of heaven for people to call on to save them.
original_subject: THE CONSEQUENCE OF REJECTING THE HOLY SPIRIT
original_verse_text: Dear friends, if we deliberately continue sinning after we have received the full knowledge of the truth, there is no other sacrifice that will cover these sins.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, recognizing the gravity of rejecting Your Son, the only name given under heaven by which we must be saved. Help us to cling steadfastly to the truth of the Gospel, not to be swayed by the temptations of the world or the allure of false religions. May we always be responsive to the leading of Your Holy Spirit, who speaks to us of Your saving love. Forgive us when we falter, and strengthen our faith to persevere in the truth. We pray this in the precious name of Jesus Christ, our Lord and Savior. Amen.
reflection: When people deliberately reject Christ's offer of salvation, they reject God's most precious gift. They ignore the leading of the Holy Spirit, the One who communicates to us God's saving love. This warning was given to the Jewish Christians who were tempted to reject Christ for another religion or, having understood Christ's atoning work. If anyone deliberately rejects the sacrifice of Christ after clearly understanding the Good News teaching about it, there is no way for that person to be saved, because God does not provide any other name in all of heaven for people to call on to save them.
subject: The Consequence of Rejecting the Holy Spirit
verse_text: Dear friends, if we deliberately continue sinning after we have received the full knowledge of the truth, there is no other sacrifice that will cover these sins.

*Today’s Verse:*

*For I can do everything with the help of Christ who*

* gives me the strength I need.. *(Phil. 4:13)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Can we really do everything? The power we receive

in union with Christ is sufficient to do His will *and*

to face the challenges that arise from our commitment

to do it. He does not grant us superhuman ability to

accomplish anything we can imagine without regard

to His interests. As we contend for the faith, we will

face troubles, pressures, and trials. *As they come, ask*

* Christ to strengthen you.*

* Pastor Sather*

Yet, in Your grace, You have promised that Your power is made perfect in our weakness. Strengthen us, Lord, that we may boldly proclaim Your gospel and contend for the faith, even in the midst of troubles and pressures. May we find our sufficiency in Christ, who empowers us to do all things according to Your will. Amen.

subject   : Subject: A SPIRITUAL THRIST (12-12-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Fri, 11 Dec 2020 17:49:46 -0600
===================================================================

*Today’s Verse:*

*God has made everything beautiful for its own*

* time. He has planted eternity in the human*

* heart, but even so people cannot see the whole *

*scope of God’s work from beginning to end.*

(Eccl. 3:11)



*Today’s Reflection:*

God has “planted eternity in the human heart.”

This means that we can never be completely

satisfied with earthly pleasures and pursuits.

Because we are created in God image, (1) we

have a spiritual thirst, (2) we have eternal

value, and (3) nothing but the eternal God

can truly satisfy us. He has built in us a rest-

less yearning for the kind of perfect world

that can only be found in His perfect rule.

He has given us a glimpse of His creation.

*But* it is only a glimpse; we cannot see into

the future or comprehend everything. *SO *

*we must trust him now* * and do His work *

*on earth.*

* Pastor Sather*

You have planted eternity in our hearts, and we recognize that our earthly pursuits can never truly satisfy. Help us to trust in Your perfect plan and do Your work on this earth, even as we await the day when we will dwell in Your presence forever. May our souls thirst for You, the living God, as we seek to honor You in all we do. Amen.

*Today’s Verse: *

*Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth, *

*where moth **and rust doth corrupt. *(Mt. 6:19)



*Today’s Reflection:*

I think we all have heard of people who have

become rich, and then lost everything. Even

an average person can spend an inheritance—

or a paycheck—with lightening speed, and

have little to show for it. My advice is don’t

waste your time chasing fleeting earthly trea-

sures. Instead, store up treasures in heaven,

for such treasures will never be lost.

(See Lk. 12:33, 34 for Jesus’ teaching.

*Money seen **as an end in itself, quickly *

*traps us and cuts us off from **both God *

*and the needy.*

*Pastor Sather*

prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the wisdom found in Your Word. Help us to heed Your call to store up treasures in heaven, where moth and rust do not destroy, and where thieves do not break in and steal. May we not be consumed by the pursuit of earthly wealth, but rather seek to use our resources to glorify You and serve others. Guide us to be faithful stewards of all that You have entrusted to us. In Jesus' name, Amen.

Even an average person can spend an inheritance or a paycheck with lightning speed and have little to show for it. My advice is, don't waste your time chasing fleeting earthly treasures. Instead, store up treasures in heaven, for such treasures will never be lost. (See Luke 12:33, 34 for Jesus' teaching.) Money seen as an end in itself quickly traps us and cuts us off from both God and the needy.
subject: The Subtle Trap

*Today’s Verses:*

*You have heard that the law of Moses says ,“Love your neighbor”*

*and hate your enemy. But I say, love your enemies! Pray for those *

*who persecute you!* (Mt 6:43-44)



*Today’s Reflection:*

By telling us not to retaliate, Jesus keeps us from taking the law

into our own hands. By loving and praying for our enemies, we

can overcome evil with good. If we love our enemies and treat

them well, we will truly show that Jesus is Lord of our life. This

is possible only for those who give themselves fully to God,

because only He can deliver us from natural selfishness. *We *

*must trust the Holy Spirit to help us show love to those* *for *

*whom we may not feel love.*

*Pastor Sather*

We must trust the Holy Spirit to help us show love to those for whom we may not feel love.

Help us to heed the words of Your Son, Jesus, who commands us to love our enemies and pray for those who persecute us. Grant us the grace to overcome evil with good, that we may truly reflect Your love and mercy. May the power of the Holy Spirit work within us, delivering us from our natural selfishness and enabling us to show compassion to those who seek to do us harm. Lord, we trust in Your sovereign plan and ask that You would use us as instruments of Your peace. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Now we see things imperfectly as in a poor mirror, but *

*then we will see everything with perfect clarity. All that *

*I know now is partial and incomplete, but then I will *

*know everything completely, just as God knows me now. *

(I Cor.13:12)

Paul offers a glimpse into the future to give us hope that

face. This truth should strengthen our faith. We don’t

have all the answers now, but one day we will. *Someday *

*we will see Christ in person and be able to see with *

*God’s perspective. *

* Pastor Sather*

===================================================================

*Today’s Verse:*

*When Adam sinned, sin entered the entire human*

*race. Adams sin brought death, so **death spread *

*to everyone, for everyone **sinned. *(Ro. 5:12)



*Today’s Reflection:*

How can we be declared guilty for something

Adam did thousands of years ago? Many feel

it isn’t fair for God to judge us because of

Adam’s sin. Yet each of us confirms our her-

itage with Adam, by our sins every day. We

have the same sinful nature and are prone to

rebel against God, and we are judged for the

sins we commit. *Because we are **sinners, *

*it **isn’t fairness **we need—it’s mercy. *

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
How can we be declared guilty for something Adam did thousands of years ago? Many feel it isn’t fair for God to judge us because of
Adam’s sin. Yet each of us confirms our her itage with Adam, by our sins every day. We have the same sinful nature and are prone to rebel against God, and we are judged for the sins we commit. Because we are sinners, it isn’t fairness we need-it’s mercy.
original_verse_text: When Adam sinned, sin entered the entire human  race. Adams sin brought death, so death spread  to everyone, for everyone sinned.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we confess that we have all sinned and fallen short of Your glory, inheriting the sinful nature of Adam. Yet, in Your great mercy, You have provided a way for us to be justified freely by Your grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus. We are grateful for Your unfailing love and the forgiveness that is ours through faith in Your Son. May we walk in obedience to Your will, ever mindful of our need for Your grace. Amen.
reflection: How can we be declared guilty for something Adam did thousands of years ago? Many feel it isn't fair for God to judge us because of Adam's sin. Yet each of us confirms our heritage with Adam, by our sins every day. We have the same sinful nature and are prone to rebel against God, and we are judged for the sins we commit. Because we are sinners, it isn't fairness we need—it's mercy.
subject: What's Fair
verse_text: When Adam sinned, sin entered the entire human  race. Adams sin brought death, so death spread  to everyone, for everyone sinned.

subject   : Subject: LOVE NEVER FAILS (12-17-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Wed, 16 Dec 2020 16:31:37 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

*Today’s Verses:*

*Love is patient and kind. Love is not jealous or boastful *

*or** proud or rude. Love does not demand its own way. *

*Love is** not irritable, and it keeps no record of when it *

*has been** wronged. It is never glad about injustices but *

*rejoices **whenever the truth wins out. Love never gives *

*up, never** loses faith, is always hopeful, and endures *

*through every** circumstance. Love will last forever. *

*(I Cor. 13:4-8a)*


*Today’s Reflection:*

I believe we have all seen that our society often

confuses Love and lust. Unlike lust, God’s kind

of love is directed outward toward others not in-

ward toward ourselves. It is utterly unselfish. This

kind of love goes against our natural inclinations.

It is impossible to have this love unless God helps

us set aside our own natural desires so that we can

love and not expect anything in return. *The more *

*we* * be**come like Christ, the more love we will *

*show to others.*

* Pastor Sather *

*Subject: PERSISTENCE PAYS OFF *(12-18-20)



*Today’s Verses:*

*Keep on asking, and you will be given what you ask for. *

*Keep on looking, and you will find. Keep on knocking, *

*and the door will be opened. For everyone who asks, *

*receives. Everyone who seeks finds. And the door is *

*opened to everyone who knocks. *(* Mt.*(7:7-8)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus tells us to keep pursuing God. People often give

up after a few halfhearted efforts and conclude that God

cannot be found. But knowing God takes faith, focus,

and follow through, and Jesus assures us that we will

be rewarded. *Don’t give up in your efforts to seek God*

*Continue to ask Him for more*. *knowledge, patience, *

*wisdom, love, and under-standing. He will give them *

*to you.*

*Pastor Sather*

As your Word in Matthew 7 instructs, we ask, seek, and knock, trusting that you will open the door and grant us the wisdom and understanding we need. Like the guidance in James 1, we ask for the wisdom to navigate the complexities of life, to grow in our faith, and to persevere in our pursuit of you. Lord, fill us with your steadfast love and unwavering presence, that we may never give up in our journey to know you more deeply. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Don’t worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow will *

*bring its **own worries. Today’s troubles is enough *

*for today. .*(Mt. 6:34)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Planning for tomorrow is time well spent; worrying

about tomorrow is time wasted. Sometimes *it's* difficult

to tell the difference. Careful planning is thinking

ahead about goals, steps, and schedules, and trust

in God’s guidance. When done well, planning can

alleviate worry. Worries, by contrast, are consumed

by fear and find it difficult to trust God. *Don’t let *

*worries about tomorrow affect your **relationship *

*with God today. (Remember worry is like **a rock-*

*ing **chair, going back and forth and getting you *

*no**where.) *

*Pastor Sather*

(Remember worry is like a rock ing chair, going back and forth and getting you nowhere.)

Grant us the peace that surpasses all understanding, as we commit our cares and concerns to You, knowing that You will guide our steps. In Your Son's name, we pray. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Great is His faithfulness, His mercies begin afresh *

*each day. *(Lam. 3:23)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jeremiah knew from experience about God’s

faithfulness. God had promised that punishment

would follow disobedience and it did. But God

had also promised future restoration, and bless-

ing, and Jeremiah knew that God would keep that

promise also. *Trusting in God’s faithfulness **day *

*by day makes us confident in His great promises *

*for the future.*

* Pastor Sather *

Help us to trust in Your unwavering care, and to find our hope in the eternal blessings You have prepared for us. Amen.

*The angel replied, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of
the *

*Most-High will overshadow you So the *

*baby born to you will be holy, and He *

*will be called the Son of God. *(Lk. 1:35)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus was born without the sin that enter-

ed the world through Adam. He was born holy, just as Adam was created
sinless. In

contrast to Adam, who disobeyed God, *Jesus obeyed God*

* and was* * thus able to face sin’s conse-quences in our place** and make

*eptable* * to God. (Ro. 5:14-19*

* Pastor Sather *

*Today’s Verse:*

*“Look, the virgin shall conceive and *

*bear** a Son **and they shall name Him, Emmanuel,” **which **means, God
with *

*us”—*(Mt. 1:23)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus was called to be Immanuel

(“God with us”),

as predicted by Isaiah the prophet

(Isa. 7:14). Jesuswas God in the

flesh; thus, God was literally among

us, “with us.” Through the Holy Spirit, Christ is present today in the life
of

every believer. *Perhaps **not even *

*Isaiah understood how far-reaching*

*the meaning of Immanuel would be.*

*Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
Jesus was called to be Immanuel (“God with us”),
as predicted by Isaiah the prophet (Isaiah 7:14). Jesuswas God in the flesh; thus, God was literally among
us, “with us.” Through the Holy Spirit, Christ is present today in the life of every believer. Perhaps not even Isaiah understood how far-reaching the meaning of Immanuel would be.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we marvel at the mystery of Your Son, the Word made flesh, who dwelt among us. We give thanks that You have fulfilled Your promise to be Immanuel, God with us, through the incarnation of Jesus Christ. May we ever be aware of Your abiding presence in our lives, that we may walk in the light of Your truth and love. In the name of our Savior, Jesus, we pray. Amen.
reflection: Jesus was called to be Immanuel ("God with us"), as predicted by Isaiah the prophet (Isaiah 7:14). Jesus was God in the flesh; thus, God was literally among us, "with us." Through the Holy Spirit, Christ is present today in the life of every believer. Perhaps not even Isaiah understood how far-reaching the meaning of Immanuel would be.

*Today’s Verse:*

Paul says, *“I can do all things through Christ who *

*Strengthens me*.” (Phil 4:13)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Can we really do everything? The power we receive

in union with Christ is sufficient to do His will and

to face challenges that arise from our commitment

to do it. He *does not* grant us superhuman ability

to accomplish any-thing we can imagine without

regard for His interests. As we contend for the faith,

we will face troubles, pressures, and trials. As they

come, ask Christ to strengthen you. *Remember*

*this—We have peace that passes understanding.*

*We have joy that cannot be taken away.*

*We have love that’s everlasting.*

*We have nothing to fear and everything to*

*hope for today, tomorrow, and always.*

* Pastor Sather *

Can we really do everything? The power we receive

we will face troubles, pressures, and trials. As they
come, ask Christ to strengthen you. Remember this-We have peace that passes understanding. We have joy that cannot be taken away. We have love that’s everlasting. We have nothing to fear and everything to hope for today, tomorrow, and always.
original_verse_text: Paul says, "I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me."
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, acknowledging that our strength and ability to overcome all things comes from the power of Your Son, Jesus Christ. As we face the trials and tribulations of this world, grant us the courage and resilience to persevere, knowing that Your grace is sufficient for us. May we find peace, joy, and love in You, the source of all good things. We trust in Your boundless power, which is at work within us, to accomplish Your will and bring glory to Your name. Amen.

As they come, ask Christ to strengthen you. Remember this-We have peace that passes understanding. We have joy that cannot be taken away. We have love that’s everlasting. We have nothing to fear and everything to hope for today, tomorrow, and always.

*Today’s Verse:*

*The people who waked in darkness have seen a *

*Great Light. *(Isa. 9:2)



Today’s Reflection:

In a time of great darkness, God promised to send

a light who would shine on everyone living in the

shadow, in the shadow of death. He is both

“Wonderful Counselor” and “Mighty God.” This

message of hope was fulfilled in the birth of Christ

and the establishment of His eternal kingdom. He

came to deliver all people from their slavery to

sin. Because of this Christmas, there has been born

a time of gift giving. But, really, Christmas is a gift

itself, the never-failing reminder that, no matter

what, God is with us every step of our journey

through this life. (GOD BE WITH YOU AND YOURS

IN THE COMING YEAR, WITH ALL THE QUESTIONS

LOOMING IN LIFE.)

*Pastor & Marcie Sather*

He is both “Wonderful Counselor” and “Mighty God.” This message of hope was fulfilled in the birth of Christ and the establishment of His eternal kingdom. He came to deliver all people from their slavery to
sin. Because of this Christmas, there has been born a time of gift giving. But, really, Christmas is a gift itself, the never-failing reminder that, no matter what, God is with us every step of our journey through this life. (GOD BE WITH YOU AND YOURS IN THE COMING YEAR, WITH ALL THE QUESTIONS LOOMING IN LIFE.) Pastor & Marcie Sather

prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the light of Your Son, Jesus Christ, who has come to shine upon us and deliver us from the darkness of sin. In this season of Christmas, may we be reminded of Your steadfast presence and the eternal hope found in Your kingdom. Guide us through the uncertainties of life, and grant us the wisdom to walk in Your ways. We praise You, our Wonderful Counselor and Mighty God. Amen.

*Today’s Verses:*

*Sing a new song to the Lord! Let the whole earth *

*sing to the Lord! **Sing to the Lord; bless His name. *

*Each day proclaim the good news **that He saves. Publish His glorious
deeds among the nations. *

*Tell **everyone about the amazing things He does. *

*Great is the Lord! **He is most worthy of praise! *

*He is to be revered above all the **gods. *(Ps. 96:1-4)


*Today’s Reflection:*

The psalmist sings out his praises to God, over-whelmed by all that God has
done. As we reflect

on God’s majesty and His goodness to us, we can-

not help telling others about Him. Witnessing comes

naturally when our hearts are full of appreciation

for what He has done. God has chosen to use us to “publish His glorious
deeds among the nations.”

Praise for our great God overflows from His

creation and should overflow from our lips. *How *

*well are you **doing at telling others about God’s greatness? *

* Pastor Sather*

*Today’s Verses:*

*Jesus was born in the town of Bethlehem in Judea, during*

*the reign of King Herod. About that time some wise *

*men **from eastern lands arrived in Jerusalem, ask-*

*ing, “Where **is the newborn king of the Jews? We *

*have seen his star **as it arose, and we have come *

*to worship him.” *(Mt. 2:1-2)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Astrologer normally called wise men traveled

thousands of miles to see the king of the Jews.

When they finally found him, they responded

with joy, worship, and gifts. This is so different

from the approach people often take today. Most

expect God to come looking for them to explain

Himself, prove who He is, and give them gifts.

*But those who are wise still seek and worship *

*Jesus to**day, not for what they can get, but for *

*who He really **is.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
Astrologer normally called wise men traveled thousands of miles to see the king of the Jews. When they finally found him, they responded with joy, worship, and gifts. This is so different from the approach people often take today.
Most expect God to come looking for them to explain Himself, prove who He is, and give them gifts.
But those who are wise still seek and worship Jesus today, not for what they can get, but for who He really is.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts of wonder and adoration, just as the wise men did when they found the Christ child. Help us to be those who diligently seek You, not for the gifts You can give, but for the privilege of worshiping the King of kings. May our lives be marked by joy, reverence, and the offering of our very selves to You, the one true God. In the name of Jesus, we pray. Amen.

*Today’s Verses:*

*Continue to love each other with true Christian *

*love. Don’t forget to show hospitality to strangers,*

* for **some have, who have entertained angels with-*

*out realizing it! *(Heb. 13:1, 2)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Three Old Testament people “entertained angels

without realizing it.”(1) Abraham (Gen 18:1ff)

(2) Gideon (Jud. 6:1ff) (3) Manoah (Jud. 13:2ff).

Some people say they cannot be hospitable be-

cause their homes are not large enough or nice

enough. But even if you have no more than a table

and two chairs in a rented room, there are people

who would be grateful to spend time in your home.

Are there visitors to your church with whom you

could share a meal? Do you know single people

who would enjoy an evening of conversation? Is there any way your home
could meet the needs of traveling missionaries?

*Hospitality simply means making other people *

*feel comfortable and at** home.*

* Pastor Sather *

prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the examples of hospitality found in Your Word. May we, like Abraham, Gideon, and Manoah, be willing to welcome strangers into our homes, for in doing so, we may be entertaining angels unawares. Help us to see the needs of others and to open our hearts and our homes to them, that they may feel welcomed and cared for. Give us generous spirits and a desire to share what we have, no matter how little it may seem. We ask this in the name of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Things were written in Scriptures long ago to *

*teach us.**They give us hope and encouragement *

*as we wait pat**iently for God’s promises. *(Ro. 15:4)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The knowledge of the scriptures affects our attitude

toward the present and the future. The more we know

about what God has done in years past, the greater

the confidence we will have in what He will do in the days ahead. *We need
to diligently read our Bibles so that **we may have confidence that God’s
will is best*

*for us.*

* Pastor Sather*

May the lessons of the past instill in us a steadfast hope for the future. We thank You, Lord, for the precious gift of Your Word. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Many will come from distant lands to rebuild the *

*temple of the **Lord. and when this happens, you *

*will know my messages have **been from the Lord Almighty. All this will
happen if you carefully*

*obey the commands of the Lord. *(Zech. 6:15)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Some of God’s promises are conditional—we must obey Him to receive them.
The rebuilding of the tem-

ple required careful obedience. God would protect

the people as long as they obeyed. Casual or occas-

ional obedience, the result of a halfhearted or divided

commitment, would not lead to blessings. Many of

God’s blessings come to us as a result of diligent obedience*. **Inconsistent
obedience cannot produce consistent blessings.*

* Pastor Sather*

Today’s Verse:

*The Lord will be with thee, He will not fail thee, *

*neither **Forsake thee, fear not, neither be dismayed. *(Deut. 31:8) NKJ



*Today’s Reflection:*

Pilots put confidence in their planes. Commuters

place their confidence in trains, cares, or busses.

Each day we must put our confidence in something

or someone. If you are willing trust a plane or a car

to get you to your destination, are you willing to

trust God to guide you here on earth and to your

eternal destination? Do you trust Him more than any human being? *How
futile it is to trust anything or anyone more**than God.*

*Pastor* *Sather*

Pilots put confidence in their planes. Commuters place their confidence in trains, cares, or busses. Each day we must put our confidence in something or someone. If you are willing trust a plane or a car to get you to your destination, are you willing to trust God to guide you here on earth and to your
eternal destination? Do you trust Him more than any human being? How futile it is to trust anything or anyone morethan God. Pastor Sather
original_verse_text: The Lord will be with thee, He will not fail thee,  neither Forsake thee, fear not, neither be dismayed.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, acknowledging that our confidence should be placed in You alone. As we navigate the journey of life, may we remember Your promise to Joshua - that You will never leave us nor forsake us. Help us to trust in Your guidance, for You are the only true source of strength and wisdom. May our faith in You be stronger than our faith in any earthly thing or person. We give thanks for Your unwavering presence and steadfast love. Amen.

Do you trust Him more than any human being? How futile it is to trust anything or anyone more than God. Pastor Sather

*Today’s Verse:*

*Come boldly to the throne of grace, that you may receive **mercy, and find
grace, for help in time of *

*need. *(Heb. 4:16)



*Today’s Reflection:*

What a wonderful thought; God the creator of all

things invites us mere creatures to pray, and He

assures us that He will hear. Great things can happen when we pray. We are
commanded to pray by the one who loves us. We show Him our love by keeping
His commandments. *Yet knowing **all this many of us *

*pray so little! Let us pray more in 2021 **so that *

*things will be better than they were in 2020.*

* Pastor Sather*

*Today’s Verses:*

*Always be joyful. Keep on praying. No matter what happens, **always be
thankful, for this is God’s will *

*for you who belong **to Jesus Christ. *(I Thess. 5:16,

17, 18)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Our joy, prayers, and thankfulness should not fluct-

uate with our circumstances or feelings. Obeying

these three commands, be joyful, keep praying, and

be thankful—often goes against our natural inclina-

tions. When we make a conscious decision to do

what God says, however, we will begin to see people

in a new perspective*. When we do God’s will we *

*find it easier to **be joyful and thankful.*

* Pastor Sather*

*HAVE--A--BLESSED--NEW--YEAR*

original_verse_text: Always be joyful. Keep on praying. No matter what happens, always be thankful, for this is God’s will  for you who belong to Jesus Christ.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, acknowledging that our joy, prayers, and thankfulness should not be dictated by our circumstances or feelings, but by Your unchanging love and faithfulness. Help us to obey Your commands, to be joyful always, to pray continually, and to give thanks in all situations, for this is Your will for us. May our lives reflect the transformative power of Your Spirit, that others may see Your goodness and be drawn to You. In Jesus' name, Amen.
